subrequirements.name: GER 371 - Contemporary German Culture

course.name: Contemporary German Culture
course.description: This course introduces students topics that shape contemporary Germany. We will examine a broad range of topics addressed in films, literature, public debates and consider Germany's role in a global setting.

subrequirements.name: GER 325 - History of German Cinema

course.name: History of German Cinema
course.description: The important films in the development of German cinema of the pre-1945 period and the cinema of the Federal Republic of Germany after 1945 to the present. Taught in English.

subrequirements.name: GER 320 - History of Tolerance from the Middle Ages to the Eighteenth Century and Beyond

course.name: History of Tolerance from the Middle Ages to the Eighteenth Century and Beyond
course.full_name: GER 320 - History of Tolerance from the Middle Ages to the Eighteenth Century and Beyond
course.description: Today, more than ever, we need to discuss and explore the topic of tolerance, and examine the roots of this philosophical and ethical approach to human life. We will trace the discourse on toleration and then tolerance from biblical times through the Middle Ages until the late eighteenth century, giving equal weight to ancient, medieval, Renaissance, and Enlightenment texts, such as romances, poetry, treatises, plays, and prose novellas. The course intends to educate students about the history of tolerance and make them to experts in the relevant discourse.

subrequirements.name: GER 312 - War, Death, and the Hero: Medieval Epics: Beowulf, Nibelungenlied, and Rolandslied

course.name: War, Death, and the Hero: Medieval Epics: Beowulf, Nibelungenlied, and Rolandslied
course.full_name: GER 312 - War, Death, and the Hero: Medieval Epics: Beowulf, Nibelungenlied, and Rolandslied
course.description: Introduce students to at least three of the most important European/German heroic epics and to challenge them in their thinking about war and death, and the role of the hero.

subrequirements.name: Tier II Arts
Tier II Arts
TAR 303 - From Ritual to Rap: Voices of American Musical Theatre

course.name: From Ritual to Rap: Voices of American Musical Theatre
course.full_name: TAR 303 - From Ritual to Rap: Voices of American Musical Theatre
course.description: From Ritual to Rap explores the political and artistic development of musical theatre with a focus on race, religion, gender, diversity, sexuality, and conflict around political struggles for equality. Marginalized voices from our culture are explored through the lens of contemporary musical theatre performance. A survey of historical theatrical conventions beginning with Nineteenth Century American influences and culminating in the current art form and focusing on contemporary performances, and including a survey of important Broadway works from Show Boat to Hamilton.

subrequirements.name: TAR 103 - Broadway and Beyond: The Art and Process of Theatre

course.name: Broadway and Beyond: The Art and Process of Theatre
course.full_name: TAR 103 - Broadway and Beyond: The Art and Process of Theatre
course.description: An introduction to the art used in producing the play: directing, acting, technical production.

subrequirements.name: TAR 100 - Acting for Everyone

course.name: Acting for Everyone
course.description: The craft of acting with emphasis on body, voice and mind. Theoretical background and practical experience, including in-class performances of selected scenes.

subrequirements.name: RELI 345 - Religion and the Arts in India

course.name: Religion and the Arts in India
course.full_name: RELI 345 - Religion and the Arts in India
course.description: Will examine the role of the visual, material, literary, and performance arts in the construction of religious knowledge in the religious traditions of India. The primary focus will be the historical development of the arts and aesthetic styles in Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam, Jainism, Sikhism, and Christianity in South Asia.

subrequirements.name: RELI 227 - Religion and  Film

course.name: Religion and  Film
course.description: This course explores religion and its relationship with visual storytelling culture. We will analyze, explore, and challenge various religious, pop-cultural, ideological, and moral messages as presented in various types of film, from art house cinema to blockbuster movies, and genres ranging from horror to comedy.

subrequirements.name: MUS 360 - Music Fundamentals through Experience

course.name: Music Fundamentals through Experience
course.description: Music skills, concepts and information learned through playing, singing and focused listening. Emphasis on beginning experiences with autoharp, guitar, recorder and voice. No prior musical training is assumed.

subrequirements.name: MUS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music

course.name: Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.full_name: MUS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.description: Examination of the traditional folk music of Mexico and its influence.  This course covers the history and evolution of the mariachi as well as the vast potpourri of Mexican music traditions. A working knowledge of Spanish is helpful but not required.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 335 - Musical Communities in North America

course.name: Musical Communities in North America
course.full_name: MUS 335 - Musical Communities in North America
course.description: This course focuses on music and place in musical communities in the United States and Canada. Emphasis is on musical styles, genres and customs in Native American, African American, Latin American, Irish American, and Asian American communities. We will investigate local Native American and borderland traditions, First Nations music in Canada, southern roots of gospel, Japanese taiko in the U.S., music and dance in U.S. and Canadian South Asian communities, and Arab American and Iranian music in Canada and the U.S.. We will explore in-depth the local communities for evidence of these and other locally maintained musical traditions.

subrequirements.name: MUS 334 - Music in World Cultures

course.name: Music in World Cultures
course.description: An introduction to the diversity of the world's musical practices and the tools of ethnomusicology as applied to case studies illustrating important ways that humans create and use music.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 328 - American Pop Music: Sinatra Era

course.name: American Pop Music: Sinatra Era
course.full_name: MUS 328 - American Pop Music: Sinatra Era
course.description: American popular music associated with Tin Pan Alley and the American musical theater through the recordings and interpretations of Frank Sinatra.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 231 - Jazz History

course.name: Jazz History
course.description: Development of Jazz in the United States.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 109 - Rock and American Popular Music

course.name: Rock and American Popular Music
course.full_name: MUS 109 - Rock and American Popular Music
course.description: This course is a survey of music of the rock era.  In addition to highlighting individuals and particular pieces of music, this course will address issues including the role music plays in shaping social interaction, and worldview.  Students will be required to heighten listening skills in order to characterize different musical styles and genres.  Students will be required to demonstrate critical thinking skills through written and verbal presentations.  This course is open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 107 - Understanding Music through Listening

course.name: Understanding Music through Listening
course.description: Development of listening skills and an understanding of music in human life through the introductory study of Western art music, world music, and jazz.  This course is open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major. Development of listening skills through introductory study of Western art music, world music, and jazz.

subrequirements.name: MUS 101A - Exploring Music through Piano for General Students

course.name: Exploring Music through Piano for General Students
course.full_name: MUS 101A - Exploring Music through Piano for General Students
course.description: This is an interactive course in music, open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.  This course explores the creative nature and process of making music at the piano. A goal of the course is to provide a basis for lifelong valuing of the musical experience and music making so that the student will continue with the piano as a source of self-expression and growth. The course introduces and develops an understanding of the basic concepts of music and the fundamentals of the keyboard. Improvisation and composition, sight-reading, playing by ear, harmonization, solo and ensemble keyboard repertoire, and applications of music technology will be creatively explored throughout the course.

subrequirements.name: MUS 100 - Basic Musicianship

course.name: Basic Musicianship
course.description: Introduction to the rudiments of musical notation, harmony, rhythm and melody.  This course is open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MAS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music

course.name: Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.full_name: MAS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.description: Examination of the traditional folk music of Mexico and its influence.  This course covers the history and evolution of the mariachi as well as the vast potpourri of Mexican music traditions. A working knowledge of Spanish is helpful but not required.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: LAS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music

course.name: Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.full_name: LAS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.description: Examination of the traditional folk music of Mexico and its influence.  This course covers the history and evolution of the mariachi as well as the vast potpourri of Mexican music traditions. A working knowledge of Spanish is helpful but not required.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: LAS 322 - Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art

course.name: Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art
course.full_name: LAS 322 - Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art
course.description: Survey of the native, prehispanic arts of Meso; Central and South America; art since the conquest of Mexico, Central and South America; and Hispanic Arts of the Southwest and contemporary Chicano art.

subrequirements.name: JPN 245 - Japanese Anime and Visual Culture

course.name: Japanese Anime and Visual Culture
course.full_name: JPN 245 - Japanese Anime and Visual Culture
course.description: This course will explore contemporary Japanese society by investigating its colorful, dynamic, and rich output of visual culture. More specifically, we will look at manga, cinematic anime, and items of material culture, illustrating how these examples of popular art teach us about the various aspects of life in Japan.

subrequirements.name: ISTA 301 - Computing and the Arts

course.name: Computing and the Arts
course.description: This course examines the ways in which computing and information science support and facilitate the production and creation of art in current society. A particular focus of the course will be to discuss how artists have used advances in technology and computing capacity to explore new ways of making art, and to investigate the relationships between technical innovation and the artistic process.

subrequirements.name: HNRS 222 - Explorations in Creative Writing

course.name: Explorations in Creative Writing
course.description: Part critical studies and part writing workshop, this class engages students with various forms of creative writing (non-fiction, fiction, poetry, hybrid forms) with an emphasis on understanding writing as a craft-based discipline. Through close reading, analysis, writing, research, and participation in community events, students will generate and revise original critical and creative writing. The class will foster critical and creative synthesis through reading, discussion, invention, research, and revision.  The course is comprised of three phases; craft devices, research, and workshop.

prereq.description: Student must be active in the Honors College.

subrequirements.name: HNRS 216 - An Encounter with Poets and Their Poetry

course.name: An Encounter with Poets and Their Poetry
course.full_name: HNRS 216 - An Encounter with Poets and Their Poetry
course.description: This Honors course is taught in conjunction with the UA Visiting Poets and Writers Reading Series.  Class members read and discuss current work of the invited writers during class time, and attend several evening public readings sponsored by the Poetry Center.  Most writers attend the class for a discussion of their writing.  In addition to the critical study of contemporary writing, class members experiment with their own creative writing.

prereq.description: Student must be active in the Honors College.

subrequirements.name: HNRS 203H - Art as Awareness

course.name: Art as Awareness
course.description: What is art and what is art "for" are the central questions in this course.  Students will explore both the experience and the practice of art on a personal, social, cultural, political, and spiritual level.  This is an interdisciplinary course that will involve both a critical study and practice of art.  Students will engage in reading, writing, studio/gallery visits, and individual practice.

prereq.description: Student must be active in the Honors College.

subrequirements.name: FTV 375 - Television and U.S. Culture

course.name: Television and U.S. Culture
course.description: Survey of the three major eras of US television with attention to key programs, technology, critical reception, audience, and relation to other arts: broadcast era; cable era; transmedia era.

subrequirements.name: FTV 352 - Looking at Movies: Film Styles and Genres

course.name: Looking at Movies: Film Styles and Genres
course.full_name: FTV 352 - Looking at Movies: Film Styles and Genres
course.description: This course provides non-majors an introduction to the history and aesthetics of cinema as a major art form of the 20th century. We will examine the technology of the moving image, analyze the visual aesthetics and styles of filmmaking in successive historical periods, and chart the development of visual narrative forms and genres in selected examples from the history of film.

subrequirements.name: ENGL 210 - Introduction to the Writing of Fiction

course.name: Introduction to the Writing of Fiction
course.full_name: ENGL 210 - Introduction to the Writing of Fiction
course.description: Beginning techniques of fiction writing, taught through exercises, the writing of original fiction, and readings in contemporary fiction.

subrequirements.name: ENGL 209 - Introduction to the Writing of Poetry

course.name: Introduction to the Writing of Poetry
course.full_name: ENGL 209 - Introduction to the Writing of Poetry
course.description: Beginning techniques of poetry writing, taught through exercises, the writing of original poetry, and readings in contemporary poetry.

subrequirements.name: ENGL 201 - Introduction to the Writing of Creative Nonfiction

course.name: Introduction to the Writing of Creative Nonfiction
course.full_name: ENGL 201 - Introduction to the Writing of Creative Nonfiction
course.description: This course is intended to give students a practical understanding of beginning techniques of nonfiction writing, taught through exercises, the writing of original nonfiction, and readings in contemporary nonfiction.  The course complements existing courses in poetry (ENGL209) and fiction (ENGL210).  All three courses are intended to improve undergraduate education by providing contact hours with Creative Writing faculty members early in the undergraduate's course of study.

subrequirements.name: DNC 200 - History of Dance

course.name: History of Dance
course.description: History of dance in western civilization from ancient Egypt to the present.

subrequirements.name: DNC 179A - Introduction to Folk Dances from Europe and the Mid East

course.name: Introduction to Folk Dances from Europe and the Mid East
course.full_name: DNC 179A - Introduction to Folk Dances from Europe and the Mid East
course.description:
In this course, we will explore folk traditions as they are expressed through dance in Europe and the Middle East and in the descendant traditions in the diasporic communities in North America. Students will learn about different styles of participatory community dancing as it is done throughout these regions. Students will learn about the contexts (celebrations, gatherings, weddings, etc.) in which dances are done and about how dance is used to establish social hierarchies, communicate cultural values, and mark dancers for cultural identity and ideology. 
The exploration of dance as a form of individual and group expression will be fostered through movement, written assignments and discussions. Upon completing this course, students will acquire a deeper appreciation for the dance in traditional and modern folk cultures.

subrequirements.name: DNC 178C - Intermediate Hip-Hop Dance Technique

course.name: Intermediate Hip-Hop Dance Technique
course.description: The purpose of this course is to further the student's knowledge and movement experience in the genre of hip-hop dance using key concepts, practical technique, artistic expression, historical understanding, and vocabulary specific to hip-hop dance. Students will expand upon learned positions and steps of hip-hop dance including but not limited to Break Dance, Locking, Popping and other social dance styles as they pertain to hip-hop. Class time will be geared toward body alignment, energy, movement quality and effectively gaining the strength, conditioning and the confidence necessary for execution of hip-hop movement. Practical elements in this course learned in the classroom will be supported outside of class through observation and written assignments.

subrequirements.name: DNC 178A - Beginning Hip-Hop Dance Technique

course.name: Beginning Hip-Hop Dance Technique
course.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce beginning students to the genre of hip-hop dance using key concepts, practical technique, artistic expression, historical understanding, and vocabulary specific to hip-hop dance. Students will learn positions and steps of basic hip-hop dance including but not limited to Break Dance, Locking, Popping and social dance styles as they pertain to hip-hop. Class time will be geared toward body alignment, energy, movement quality and effectively gaining the strength, conditioning and confidence necessary for execution of hip-hop movement. Practical elements in this course learned in the classroom will be supported outside of class through observation and written assignments.

subrequirements.name: DNC 177D - Dance Afrikana Intermediate Level

course.name: Dance Afrikana Intermediate Level
course.description: Traditional dances from continental Africa and throughout the African diaspora will be practiced in this course at an intermediate level. Students will learn rhythms and movements specific to the dance traditions of various ethnic groups. Oral folklore and songs will be taught as well.

subrequirements.name: DNC 177C - Dance Afrikana Introductory Level

course.name: Dance Afrikana Introductory Level
course.description: Traditional dances from continental Africa and throughout the  African diaspora will be introduced in this course.  Students will learn rhythms and movements specific to the dance traditions of various ethnic groups.  Oral folklore and songs will be taught as well.

subrequirements.name: DNC 176A - Introduction to Tap Dance

course.name: Introduction to Tap Dance
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills and aesthetic sensibilities at a beginning level.  No previous experience in tap dance is necessary. Differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 175 - Theatre Dance

course.name: Theatre Dance
course.description: Jazz movement styles for the beginning dancer; basic steps, phrases, and performing techniques for musical comedy and media dance entertainment.

subrequirements.name: DNC 152C - Intermediate Modern Dance

course.name: Intermediate Modern Dance
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills an aesthetic sensibilities at a moderately sophisticated level.  Appropriate for students with 4-8 semesters of prior modern dance training.  Subtle differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 152B - Modern Dance with Limited Experience

course.name: Modern Dance with Limited Experience
course.full_name: DNC 152B - Modern Dance with Limited Experience
course.description: Modern dance basic skills and new rhythmic challenges incorporated to advance the beginner to a higher performance level.  Explores a variety of music styles.

subrequirements.name: DNC 152A - Beginning Modern Dance

course.name: Beginning Modern Dance
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills and aesthetic sensibilities at a beginning level.  No previous experience in modern dance is necessary. Differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 144C - Intermediate Jazz Dance

course.name: Intermediate Jazz Dance
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills an aesthetic sensibilities at a moderately sophisticated level.  Appropriate for students with 4-8 semesters of prior jazz dance training.  Subtle differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 144B - Jazz Dance for Beginners with Limited Experience

course.name: Jazz Dance for Beginners with Limited Experience
course.full_name: DNC 144B - Jazz Dance for Beginners with Limited Experience
course.description: Jazz dance basic skills and new rhythmic challenges incorporated to advance the beginner to a higher performance level.  Explores a variety of music styles.

subrequirements.name: DNC 144A - Introduction to Jazz Dance

course.name: Introduction to Jazz Dance
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills and aesthetic sensibilities at a beginning level.  No previous experience in jazz dance is necessary. Differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 143 - Improvisation

course.name: Improvisation
course.description: Improvisation for non-majors and those students in education desiring certification for teaching dance K-12.

subrequirements.name: DNC 112C - Intermediate Ballet

course.name: Intermediate Ballet
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills an aesthetic sensibilities at a moderately sophisticated level.  Appropriate for students with 4-8 semesters of prior ballet training.  Subtle differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 112B - Ballet for Beginners with Limited Experience

course.name: Ballet for Beginners with Limited Experience
course.full_name: DNC 112B - Ballet for Beginners with Limited Experience
course.description: Ballet dance basic skills and new rhythmic challenges incorporated to advance the beginner to a higher performance level.  Explores a variety of music styles.

subrequirements.name: DNC 112A - Introduction to Ballet

course.name: Introduction to Ballet
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills and aesthetic sensibilities at a beginning level.  No previous experience in ballet dance is necessary. Differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 101 - Dance Appreciation

course.name: Dance Appreciation
course.description: Students will explore dance as a communicative and multicultural art form in society. This course is an introduction to the aesthetic and critical dimensions of viewing various genres of theatrical, ethnological and ritual dance. Students will critically engage with the field of dance by viewing numerous dance videos, gaining awareness and understanding of dance forms, acknowledging personal aesthetic values, and by forming a well-rounded appreciation for dance.

subrequirements.name: DNC 100 - Looking at Dance

course.name: Looking at Dance
course.description: Origins of dance as human expression in ritual, social, and theatrical context. Twentieth century developments in ballet, modern dance, movie, and show dancing.

subrequirements.name: CLAS 310 - Rome in Film: The City as Text

course.name: Rome in Film: The City as Text
course.full_name: CLAS 310 - Rome in Film: The City as Text
course.description: A grand tour of Rome in film, beginning with the epic themes of ancient history-the Caesars, Cleopatra, and Mark Anthony-through the modern period . Films in their thematic, stylistic, and narrative range invite students to explore both Rome's unique status in the west as well as Rome's place in the national Italian consciousness.

subrequirements.name: ART 358 - Design: Cultural and Language

course.name: Design: Cultural and Language
course.description: This course examines issues, principles, methodologies, theories and visual language of graphic design, illustration and new media. Student will be required to keep a journal, write a research paper, and create four visual projects and on-line discussions.

subrequirements.name: ART 282 - Underground: Street Art and Culture

course.name: Underground: Street Art and Culture
course.full_name: ART 282 - Underground: Street Art and Culture
course.description:
Underground: Street Art and Culture is an introduction to contemporary artists and works produced outside of conventional museum and gallery contexts. Through a series of lectures and labs, we explore art practices including graffiti art, tattoos, and outsider art through documentary videos, directed readings, and studio projects.  Students are required to explore on and off campus venues to complete writing assignments, participate in discussions, and realize project goals.  
In each genre we will examine principle artists, vocabulary, and the cultural significance of the work produced. As a lecture/lab course, projects develop out of lecture materials and discussions, and are broadened through research-based experiences. This course will highlight the conceptual, technical, and visual foundations of underground art works.

subrequirements.name: ART 242 - Introduction to Photographic Concepts

course.name: Introduction to Photographic Concepts
course.description: Introduction to photographic history and processes: aesthetics, theory and criticism. This is a non-darkroom photography course that utilizes digital media capture and twenty-first century web-based presentation methods.

subrequirements.name: ART 203 - Survey of Contemporary Studio Art

course.name: Survey of Contemporary Studio Art
course.full_name: ART 203 - Survey of Contemporary Studio Art
course.description: This course explores the role of studio art and visual culture in contemporary society. It is a survey of contemporary art designed to introduce you to the history and theory of contemporary visual arts practices from 1980 to the present. We will examine art-making practices and explore connections between the arts, pop culture, and society at large. The course will serve as a framework within which contemporary artworks can be discussed.

subrequirements.name: ARH 329 - Art History of the Cinema

course.name: Art History of the Cinema
course.full_name: ARH 329 - Art History of the Cinema
course.description: Survey of major artistic movements, including academicism, expressionism, cubism, and surrealism, and their influence on film in Germany, Italy, America, and France.

subrequirements.name: ARH 325 - History of Modern Architecture

course.name: History of Modern Architecture
course.description: This course is a historical and theoretical survey of significant developments in modern architecture since the industrial revolution. It will consider the impact of changing philosophies and technologies that have impacted the modern view of the built environment. Special focus will be placed on 19th-century historicism, early 20th-century avant-gardes, and Post-WWII practices that embraced sociology and new types of technology.

subrequirements.name: ARH 324 - Introduction to the History of Photography

course.name: Introduction to the History of Photography
course.full_name: ARH 324 - Introduction to the History of Photography
course.description: This course will survey the history of photography as an art form and a means of visual communication.

subrequirements.name: ARH 322 - Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art

course.name: Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art
course.full_name: ARH 322 - Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art
course.description: Survey of the native, prehispanic arts of Meso; Central and South America; art since the conquest of Mexico, Central and South America; and Hispanic Arts of the Southwest and contemporary Chicano art.

subrequirements.name: ARH 320 - Introduction to European Modern Art

course.name: Introduction to European Modern Art
course.full_name: ARH 320 - Introduction to European Modern Art
course.description: Painting and sculpture in Europe from about 1886 to recent times.

subrequirements.name: ARH 319 - Introduction to American Art

course.name: Introduction to American Art
course.description: Survey of American architecture, painting, sculpture, photography, and the decorative arts from colonial times to present.

subrequirements.name: ARH 316B - Survey of Eighteenth-Century Art

course.name: Survey of Eighteenth-Century Art
course.description: A survey of European Art and Architecture from the eighteenth-century. The lecture will examine the major artists, artistic monuments and movements of the eighteenth-century and address, more specifically, some of the critical issues in the studies of eighteenth-century art.

subrequirements.name: ARH 316A - Survey of Baroque Art & Culture

course.name: Survey of Baroque Art & Culture
course.full_name: ARH 316A - Survey of Baroque Art & Culture
course.description: A survey of Western Art and Architecture in seventeenth-century Europe. This lecture course will examine the major artists, artistic monuments and movements of the seventeenth-century and address the critical issues in the study of seventeenth-century art.

subrequirements.name: ARH 315 - Survey of Baroque and Rococo Art

course.name: Survey of Baroque and Rococo Art
course.full_name: ARH 315 - Survey of Baroque and Rococo Art
course.description: An in-depth survey of western European art and architecture from 1600 to 1780. Emphasis will be placed on the  interpretation of, and critical thinking about the social function and content of art.

subrequirements.name: ARH 203 - Survey of Art in Non-Euro/American Societies

course.name: Survey of Art in Non-Euro/American Societies
course.full_name: ARH 203 - Survey of Art in Non-Euro/American Societies
course.description: An interdisciplinary survey of arts and architecture of Africa, Mesoamerica, Native North America, and the Pacific Basin.

subrequirements.name: ARH 201 - Survey of Western Art in Society: Prehistory through Gothic

course.name: Survey of Western Art in Society: Prehistory through Gothic
course.full_name: ARH 201 - Survey of Western Art in Society: Prehistory through Gothic
course.description: A survey of the art and architecture of western civilization from prehistoric cultures through the Gothic period utilizing interdisciplinary methods.  The lectures will focus on the major monuments of art and will examine the relationship between the social function of art and its form and content.

subrequirements.name: ARE 130 - Exploring Art and Visual Culture

course.name: Exploring Art and Visual Culture
course.full_name: ARE 130 - Exploring Art and Visual Culture
course.description: How can we create and define art and visual culture? This course is an introduction to understanding how contemporary art and visual culture impacts our lives and can be a meaningful part of living. It includes discussion, lecture, breakout groups, and some explorations of hands-on art making. Students will examine why art and visual culture are made and who makes it, and explore how we can connect to and comment on art and visual culture through engagement with art.

subrequirements.name: ARC 325 - History of Modern Architecture

course.name: History of Modern Architecture
course.description: This course is a historical and theoretical survey of significant developments in modern architecture since the industrial revolution. It will consider the impact of changing philosophies and technologies that have impacted the modern view of the built environment. Special focus will be placed on 19th-century historicism, early 20th-century avant-gardes, and Post-WWII practices that embraced sociology and new types of technology.

subrequirements.name: Tier II Arts
TAR 303 - From Ritual to Rap: Voices of American Musical Theatre

course.name: From Ritual to Rap: Voices of American Musical Theatre
course.full_name: TAR 303 - From Ritual to Rap: Voices of American Musical Theatre
course.description: From Ritual to Rap explores the political and artistic development of musical theatre with a focus on race, religion, gender, diversity, sexuality, and conflict around political struggles for equality. Marginalized voices from our culture are explored through the lens of contemporary musical theatre performance. A survey of historical theatrical conventions beginning with Nineteenth Century American influences and culminating in the current art form and focusing on contemporary performances, and including a survey of important Broadway works from Show Boat to Hamilton.

subrequirements.name: TAR 103 - Broadway and Beyond: The Art and Process of Theatre

course.name: Broadway and Beyond: The Art and Process of Theatre
course.full_name: TAR 103 - Broadway and Beyond: The Art and Process of Theatre
course.description: An introduction to the art used in producing the play: directing, acting, technical production.

subrequirements.name: TAR 100 - Acting for Everyone

course.name: Acting for Everyone
course.description: The craft of acting with emphasis on body, voice and mind. Theoretical background and practical experience, including in-class performances of selected scenes.

subrequirements.name: RELI 345 - Religion and the Arts in India

course.name: Religion and the Arts in India
course.full_name: RELI 345 - Religion and the Arts in India
course.description: Will examine the role of the visual, material, literary, and performance arts in the construction of religious knowledge in the religious traditions of India. The primary focus will be the historical development of the arts and aesthetic styles in Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam, Jainism, Sikhism, and Christianity in South Asia.

subrequirements.name: RELI 227 - Religion and  Film

course.name: Religion and  Film
course.description: This course explores religion and its relationship with visual storytelling culture. We will analyze, explore, and challenge various religious, pop-cultural, ideological, and moral messages as presented in various types of film, from art house cinema to blockbuster movies, and genres ranging from horror to comedy.

subrequirements.name: MUS 360 - Music Fundamentals through Experience

course.name: Music Fundamentals through Experience
course.description: Music skills, concepts and information learned through playing, singing and focused listening. Emphasis on beginning experiences with autoharp, guitar, recorder and voice. No prior musical training is assumed.

subrequirements.name: MUS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music

course.name: Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.full_name: MUS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.description: Examination of the traditional folk music of Mexico and its influence.  This course covers the history and evolution of the mariachi as well as the vast potpourri of Mexican music traditions. A working knowledge of Spanish is helpful but not required.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 335 - Musical Communities in North America

course.name: Musical Communities in North America
course.full_name: MUS 335 - Musical Communities in North America
course.description: This course focuses on music and place in musical communities in the United States and Canada. Emphasis is on musical styles, genres and customs in Native American, African American, Latin American, Irish American, and Asian American communities. We will investigate local Native American and borderland traditions, First Nations music in Canada, southern roots of gospel, Japanese taiko in the U.S., music and dance in U.S. and Canadian South Asian communities, and Arab American and Iranian music in Canada and the U.S.. We will explore in-depth the local communities for evidence of these and other locally maintained musical traditions.

subrequirements.name: MUS 334 - Music in World Cultures

course.name: Music in World Cultures
course.description: An introduction to the diversity of the world's musical practices and the tools of ethnomusicology as applied to case studies illustrating important ways that humans create and use music.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 328 - American Pop Music: Sinatra Era

course.name: American Pop Music: Sinatra Era
course.full_name: MUS 328 - American Pop Music: Sinatra Era
course.description: American popular music associated with Tin Pan Alley and the American musical theater through the recordings and interpretations of Frank Sinatra.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 231 - Jazz History

course.name: Jazz History
course.description: Development of Jazz in the United States.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 109 - Rock and American Popular Music

course.name: Rock and American Popular Music
course.full_name: MUS 109 - Rock and American Popular Music
course.description: This course is a survey of music of the rock era.  In addition to highlighting individuals and particular pieces of music, this course will address issues including the role music plays in shaping social interaction, and worldview.  Students will be required to heighten listening skills in order to characterize different musical styles and genres.  Students will be required to demonstrate critical thinking skills through written and verbal presentations.  This course is open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 107 - Understanding Music through Listening

course.name: Understanding Music through Listening
course.description: Development of listening skills and an understanding of music in human life through the introductory study of Western art music, world music, and jazz.  This course is open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major. Development of listening skills through introductory study of Western art music, world music, and jazz.

subrequirements.name: MUS 101A - Exploring Music through Piano for General Students

course.name: Exploring Music through Piano for General Students
course.full_name: MUS 101A - Exploring Music through Piano for General Students
course.description: This is an interactive course in music, open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major. subrequirements.name: HNRS 203H - Art as Awareness

course.name: Art as Awareness
course.description: What is art and what is art "for" are the central questions in this course.  Students will explore both the experience and the practice of art on a personal, social, cultural, political, and spiritual level.  This is an interdisciplinary course that will involve both a critical study and practice of art.  Students will engage in reading, writing, studio/gallery visits, and individual practice.

prereq.description: Student must be active in the Honors College.

subrequirements.name: FTV 375 - Television and U.S. Culture

course.name: Television and U.S. Culture
course.description: Survey of the three major eras of US television with attention to key programs, technology, critical reception, audience, and relation to other arts: broadcast era; cable era; transmedia era.

subrequirements.name: FTV 352 - Looking at Movies: Film Styles and Genres

course.name: Looking at Movies: Film Styles and Genres
course.full_name: FTV 352 - Looking at Movies: Film Styles and Genres
course.description: This course provides non-majors an introduction to the history and aesthetics of cinema as a major art form of the 20th century. We will examine the technology of the moving image, analyze the visual aesthetics and styles of filmmaking in successive historical periods, and chart the development of visual narrative forms and genres in selected examples from the history of film.

subrequirements.name: ENGL 210 - Introduction to the Writing of Fiction

course.name: Introduction to the Writing of Fiction
course.full_name: ENGL 210 - Introduction to the Writing of Fiction
course.description: Beginning techniques of fiction writing, taught through exercises, the writing of original fiction, and readings in contemporary fiction.

subrequirements.name: ENGL 209 - Introduction to the Writing of Poetry

course.name: Introduction to the Writing of Poetry
course.full_name: ENGL 209 - Introduction to the Writing of Poetry
course.description: Beginning techniques of poetry writing, taught through exercises, the writing of original poetry, and readings in contemporary poetry.

subrequirements.name: ENGL 201 - Introduction to the Writing of Creative Nonfiction

course.name: Introduction to the Writing of Creative Nonfiction
course.full_name: ENGL 201 - Introduction to the Writing of Creative Nonfiction
course.description: This course is intended to give students a practical understanding of beginning techniques of nonfiction writing, taught through exercises, the writing of original nonfiction, and readings in contemporary nonfiction.  The course complements existing courses in poetry (ENGL209) and fiction (ENGL210).  All three courses are intended to improve undergraduate education by providing contact hours with Creative Writing faculty members early in the undergraduate's course of study.

subrequirements.name: DNC 200 - History of Dance

course.name: History of Dance
course.description: History of dance in western civilization from ancient Egypt to the present.

subrequirements.name: DNC 179A - Introduction to Folk Dances from Europe and the Mid East

course.name: Introduction to Folk Dances from Europe and the Mid East
course.full_name: DNC 179A - Introduction to Folk Dances from Europe and the Mid East
course.description:
In this course, we will explore folk traditions as they are expressed through dance in Europe and the Middle East and in the descendant traditions in the diasporic communities in North America. Students will learn about different styles of participatory community dancing as it is done throughout these regions. Students will learn about the contexts (celebrations, gatherings, weddings, etc.) in which dances are done and about how dance is used to establish social hierarchies, communicate cultural values, and mark dancers for cultural identity and ideology. 
The exploration of dance as a form of individual and group expression will be fostered through movement, written assignments and discussions. Upon completing this course, students will acquire a deeper appreciation for the dance in traditional and modern folk cultures.

subrequirements.name: DNC 178C - Intermediate Hip-Hop Dance Technique

course.name: Intermediate Hip-Hop Dance Technique
course.description: The purpose of this course is to further the student's knowledge and movement experience in the genre of hip-hop dance using key concepts, practical technique, artistic expression, historical understanding, and vocabulary specific to hip-hop dance. Students will expand upon learned positions and steps of hip-hop dance including but not limited to Break Dance, Locking, Popping and other social dance styles as they pertain to hip-hop. Class time will be geared toward body alignment, energy, movement quality and effectively gaining the strength, conditioning and the confidence necessary for execution of hip-hop movement. Practical elements in this course learned in the classroom will be supported outside of class through observation and written assignments.

subrequirements.name: DNC 178A - Beginning Hip-Hop Dance Technique

course.name: Beginning Hip-Hop Dance Technique
course.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce beginning students to the genre of hip-hop dance using key concepts, practical technique, artistic expression, historical understanding, and vocabulary specific to hip-hop dance. Students will learn positions and steps of basic hip-hop dance including but not limited to Break Dance, Locking, Popping and social dance styles as they pertain to hip-hop. Class time will be geared toward body alignment, energy, movement quality and effectively gaining the strength, conditioning and confidence necessary for execution of hip-hop movement. Practical elements in this course learned in the classroom will be supported outside of class through observation and written assignments.

subrequirements.name: DNC 177D - Dance Afrikana Intermediate Level

course.name: Dance Afrikana Intermediate Level
course.description: Traditional dances from continental Africa and throughout the African diaspora will be practiced in this course at an intermediate level. Students will learn rhythms and movements specific to the dance traditions of various ethnic groups. Oral folklore and songs will be taught as well.

subrequirements.name: DNC 177C - Dance Afrikana Introductory Level

course.name: Dance Afrikana Introductory Level
course.description: Traditional dances from continental Africa and throughout the  African diaspora will be introduced in this course.  Students will learn rhythms and movements specific to the dance traditions of various ethnic groups.  Oral folklore and songs will be taught as well.

subrequirements.name: DNC 176A - Introduction to Tap Dance

course.name: Introduction to Tap Dance
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills and aesthetic sensibilities at a beginning level.  No previous experience in tap dance is necessary. Differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 175 - Theatre Dance

course.name: Theatre Dance
course.description: Jazz movement styles for the beginning dancer; basic steps, phrases, and performing techniques for musical comedy and media dance entertainment.

subrequirements.name: DNC 152C - Intermediate Modern Dance

course.name: Intermediate Modern Dance
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills an aesthetic sensibilities at a moderately sophisticated level.  Appropriate for students with 4-8 semesters of prior modern dance training.  Subtle differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 152B - Modern Dance with Limited Experience

course.name: Modern Dance with Limited Experience
course.full_name: DNC 152B - Modern Dance with Limited Experience
course.description: Modern dance basic skills and new rhythmic challenges incorporated to advance the beginner to a higher performance level.  Explores a variety of music styles.

subrequirements.name: DNC 152A - Beginning Modern Dance

course.name: Beginning Modern Dance
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills and aesthetic sensibilities at a beginning level.  No previous experience in modern dance is necessary. Differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 144C - Intermediate Jazz Dance

course.name: Intermediate Jazz Dance
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills an aesthetic sensibilities at a moderately sophisticated level.  Appropriate for students with 4-8 semesters of prior jazz dance training.  Subtle differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 144B - Jazz Dance for Beginners with Limited Experience

course.name: Jazz Dance for Beginners with Limited Experience
course.full_name: DNC 144B - Jazz Dance for Beginners with Limited Experience
course.description: Jazz dance basic skills and new rhythmic challenges incorporated to advance the beginner to a higher performance level.  Explores a variety of music styles.

subrequirements.name: DNC 144A - Introduction to Jazz Dance

course.name: Introduction to Jazz Dance
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills and aesthetic sensibilities at a beginning level.  No previous experience in jazz dance is necessary. Differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 143 - Improvisation

course.name: Improvisation
course.description: Improvisation for non-majors and those students in education desiring certification for teaching dance K-12.

subrequirements.name: DNC 112C - Intermediate Ballet

course.name: Intermediate Ballet
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills an aesthetic sensibilities at a moderately sophisticated level.  Appropriate for students with 4-8 semesters of prior ballet training.  Subtle differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 112B - Ballet for Beginners with Limited Experience

course.name: Ballet for Beginners with Limited Experience
course.full_name: DNC 112B - Ballet for Beginners with Limited Experience
course.description: Ballet dance basic skills and new rhythmic challenges incorporated to advance the beginner to a higher performance level.  Explores a variety of music styles.

subrequirements.name: DNC 112A - Introduction to Ballet

course.name: Introduction to Ballet
course.description: Emphasis will be directed toward learning and developing both technical skills and aesthetic sensibilities at a beginning level.  No previous experience in ballet dance is necessary. Differences in movement quality, energy and rhythm will be explored.

subrequirements.name: DNC 101 - Dance Appreciation

course.name: Dance Appreciation
course.description: Students will explore dance as a communicative and multicultural art form in society. This course is an introduction to the aesthetic and critical dimensions of viewing various genres of theatrical, ethnological and ritual dance. Students will critically engage with the field of dance by viewing numerous dance videos, gaining awareness and understanding of dance forms, acknowledging personal aesthetic values, and by forming a well-rounded appreciation for dance.

subrequirements.name: DNC 100 - Looking at Dance

course.name: Looking at Dance
course.description: Origins of dance as human expression in ritual, social, and theatrical context. Twentieth century developments in ballet, modern dance, movie, and show dancing.

subrequirements.name: CLAS 310 - Rome in Film: The City as Text

course.name: Rome in Film: The City as Text
course.full_name: CLAS 310 - Rome in Film: The City as Text
course.description: A grand tour of Rome in film, beginning with the epic themes of ancient history-the Caesars, Cleopatra, and Mark Anthony-through the modern period . Films in their thematic, stylistic, and narrative range invite students to explore both Rome's unique status in the west as well as Rome's place in the national Italian consciousness.

subrequirements.name: ART 358 - Design: Cultural and Language

course.name: Design: Cultural and Language
course.description: This course examines issues, principles, methodologies, theories and visual language of graphic design, illustration and new media. Student will be required to keep a journal, write a research paper, and create four visual projects and on-line discussions.

subrequirements.name: ART 282 - Underground: Street Art and Culture

course.name: Underground: Street Art and Culture
course.full_name: ART 282 - Underground: Street Art and Culture
course.description:
Underground: Street Art and Culture is an introduction to contemporary artists and works produced outside of conventional museum and gallery contexts. Through a series of lectures and labs, we explore art practices including graffiti art, tattoos, and outsider art through documentary videos, directed readings, and studio projects.  Students are required to explore on and off campus venues to complete writing assignments, participate in discussions, and realize project goals.  
In each genre we will examine principle artists, vocabulary, and the cultural significance of the work produced. As a lecture/lab course, projects develop out of lecture materials and discussions, and are broadened through research-based experiences. This course will highlight the conceptual, technical, and visual foundations of underground art works.

subrequirements.name: ART 242 - Introduction to Photographic Concepts

course.name: Introduction to Photographic Concepts
course.description: Introduction to photographic history and processes: aesthetics, theory and criticism. This is a non-darkroom photography course that utilizes digital media capture and twenty-first century web-based presentation methods.

subrequirements.name: ART 203 - Survey of Contemporary Studio Art

course.name: Survey of Contemporary Studio Art
course.full_name: ART 203 - Survey of Contemporary Studio Art
course.description: This course explores the role of studio art and visual culture in contemporary society. It is a survey of contemporary art designed to introduce you to the history and theory of contemporary visual arts practices from 1980 to the present. We will examine art-making practices and explore connections between the arts, pop culture, and society at large. The course will serve as a framework within which contemporary artworks can be discussed.

subrequirements.name: ARH 329 - Art History of the Cinema

course.name: Art History of the Cinema
course.full_name: ARH 329 - Art History of the Cinema
course.description: Survey of major artistic movements, including academicism, expressionism, cubism, and surrealism, and their influence on film in Germany, Italy, America, and France.

subrequirements.name: ARH 325 - History of Modern Architecture

course.name: History of Modern Architecture
course.description: This course is a historical and theoretical survey of significant developments in modern architecture since the industrial revolution. It will consider the impact of changing philosophies and technologies that have impacted the modern view of the built environment. Special focus will be placed on 19th-century historicism, early 20th-century avant-gardes, and Post-WWII practices that embraced sociology and new types of technology.

subrequirements.name: ARH 324 - Introduction to the History of Photography

course.name: Introduction to the History of Photography
course.full_name: ARH 324 - Introduction to the History of Photography
course.description: This course will survey the history of photography as an art form and a means of visual communication.

subrequirements.name: ARH 322 - Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art

course.name: Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art
course.full_name: ARH 322 - Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art
course.description: Survey of the native, prehispanic arts of Meso; Central and South America; art since the conquest of Mexico, Central and South America; and Hispanic Arts of the Southwest and contemporary Chicano art.

subrequirements.name: ARH 320 - Introduction to European Modern Art

course.name: Introduction to European Modern Art
course.full_name: ARH 320 - Introduction to European Modern Art
course.description: Painting and sculpture in Europe from about 1886 to recent times.

subrequirements.name: ARH 319 - Introduction to American Art

course.name: Introduction to American Art
course.description: Survey of American architecture, painting, sculpture, photography, and the decorative arts from colonial times to present.

subrequirements.name: ARH 316B - Survey of Eighteenth-Century Art

course.name: Survey of Eighteenth-Century Art
course.description: A survey of European Art and Architecture from the eighteenth-century. The lecture will examine the major artists, artistic monuments and movements of the eighteenth-century and address, more specifically, some of the critical issues in the studies of eighteenth-century art.

subrequirements.name: ARH 316A - Survey of Baroque Art & Culture

course.name: Survey of Baroque Art & Culture
course.full_name: ARH 316A - Survey of Baroque Art & Culture
course.description: A survey of Western Art and Architecture in seventeenth-century Europe. This lecture course will examine the major artists, artistic monuments and movements of the seventeenth-century and address the critical issues in the study of seventeenth-century art.

subrequirements.name: ARH 315 - Survey of Baroque and Rococo Art

course.name: Survey of Baroque and Rococo Art
course.full_name: ARH 315 - Survey of Baroque and Rococo Art
course.description: An in-depth survey of western European art and architecture from 1600 to 1780. Emphasis will be placed on the  interpretation of, and critical thinking about the social function and content of art.

subrequirements.name: ARH 203 - Survey of Art in Non-Euro/American Societies

course.name: Survey of Art in Non-Euro/American Societies
course.full_name: ARH 203 - Survey of Art in Non-Euro/American Societies
course.description: An interdisciplinary survey of arts and architecture of Africa, Mesoamerica, Native North America, and the Pacific Basin.

subrequirements.name: ARH 201 - Survey of Western Art in Society: Prehistory through Gothic

course.name: Survey of Western Art in Society: Prehistory through Gothic
course.full_name: ARH 201 - Survey of Western Art in Society: Prehistory through Gothic
course.description: A survey of the art and architecture of western civilization from prehistoric cultures through the Gothic period utilizing interdisciplinary methods.  The lectures will focus on the major monuments of art and will examine the relationship between the social function of art and its form and content.

subrequirements.name: ARE 130 - Exploring Art and Visual Culture

course.name: Exploring Art and Visual Culture
course.full_name: ARE 130 - Exploring Art and Visual Culture
course.description: How can we create and define art and visual culture? This course is an introduction to understanding how contemporary art and visual culture impacts our lives and can be a meaningful part of living. It includes discussion, lecture, breakout groups, and some explorations of hands-on art making. Students will examine why art and visual culture are made and who makes it, and explore how we can connect to and comment on art and visual culture through engagement with art.

subrequirements.name: ARC 325 - History of Modern Architecture

course.name: History of Modern Architecture
course.description: This course is a historical and theoretical survey of significant developments in modern architecture since the industrial revolution. It will consider the impact of changing philosophies and technologies that have impacted the modern view of the built environment. Special focus will be placed on 19th-century historicism, early 20th-century avant-gardes, and Post-WWII practices that embraced sociology and new types of technology.

subrequirements.name: Tier II Arts
TAR 303 - From Ritual to Rap: Voices of American Musical Theatre

course.name: From Ritual to Rap: Voices of American Musical Theatre
course.full_name: TAR 303 - From Ritual to Rap: Voices of American Musical Theatre
course.description: From Ritual to Rap explores the political and artistic development of musical theatre with a focus on race, religion, gender, diversity, sexuality, and conflict around political struggles for equality. Marginalized voices from our culture are explored through the lens of contemporary musical theatre performance. A survey of historical theatrical conventions beginning with Nineteenth Century American influences and culminating in the current art form and focusing on contemporary performances, and including a survey of important Broadway works from Show Boat to Hamilton.

subrequirements.name: TAR 103 - Broadway and Beyond: The Art and Process of Theatre

course.name: Broadway and Beyond: The Art and Process of Theatre
course.full_name: TAR 103 - Broadway and Beyond: The Art and Process of Theatre
course.description: An introduction to the art used in producing the play: directing, acting, technical production.

subrequirements.name: TAR 100 - Acting for Everyone

course.name: Acting for Everyone
course.description: The craft of acting with emphasis on body, voice and mind. Theoretical background and practical experience, including in-class performances of selected scenes.

subrequirements.name: RELI 345 - Religion and the Arts in India

course.name: Religion and the Arts in India
course.full_name: RELI 345 - Religion and the Arts in India
course.description: Will examine the role of the visual, material, literary, and performance arts in the construction of religious knowledge in the religious traditions of India. The primary focus will be the historical development of the arts and aesthetic styles in Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam, Jainism, Sikhism, and Christianity in South Asia.

subrequirements.name: RELI 227 - Religion and  Film

course.name: Religion and  Film
course.description: This course explores religion and its relationship with visual storytelling culture. We will analyze, explore, and challenge various religious, pop-cultural, ideological, and moral messages as presented in various types of film, from art house cinema to blockbuster movies, and genres ranging from horror to comedy.

subrequirements.name: MUS 360 - Music Fundamentals through Experience

course.name: Music Fundamentals through Experience
course.description: Music skills, concepts and information learned through playing, singing and focused listening. Emphasis on beginning experiences with autoharp, guitar, recorder and voice. No prior musical training is assumed.

subrequirements.name: MUS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music

course.name: Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.full_name: MUS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.description: Examination of the traditional folk music of Mexico and its influence.  This course covers the history and evolution of the mariachi as well as the vast potpourri of Mexican music traditions. A working knowledge of Spanish is helpful but not required.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 335 - Musical Communities in North America

course.name: Musical Communities in North America
course.full_name: MUS 335 - Musical Communities in North America
course.description: This course focuses on music and place in musical communities in the United States and Canada. Emphasis is on musical styles, genres and customs in Native American, African American, Latin American, Irish American, and Asian American communities. We will investigate local Native American and borderland traditions, First Nations music in Canada, southern roots of gospel, Japanese taiko in the U.S., music and dance in U.S. and Canadian South Asian communities, and Arab American and Iranian music in Canada and the U.S.. We will explore in-depth the local communities for evidence of these and other locally maintained musical traditions.

subrequirements.name: MUS 334 - Music in World Cultures

course.name: Music in World Cultures
course.description: An introduction to the diversity of the world's musical practices and the tools of ethnomusicology as applied to case studies illustrating important ways that humans create and use music.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 328 - American Pop Music: Sinatra Era

course.name: American Pop Music: Sinatra Era
course.full_name: MUS 328 - American Pop Music: Sinatra Era
course.description: American popular music associated with Tin Pan Alley and the American musical theater through the recordings and interpretations of Frank Sinatra.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 231 - Jazz History

course.name: Jazz History
course.description: Development of Jazz in the United States.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 109 - Rock and American Popular Music

course.name: Rock and American Popular Music
course.full_name: MUS 109 - Rock and American Popular Music
course.description: This course is a survey of music of the rock era.  In addition to highlighting individuals and particular pieces of music, this course will address issues including the role music plays in shaping social interaction, and worldview.  Students will be required to heighten listening skills in order to characterize different musical styles and genres.  Students will be required to demonstrate critical thinking skills through written and verbal presentations.  This course is open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MUS 107 - Understanding Music through Listening

course.name: Understanding Music through Listening
course.description: Development of listening skills and an understanding of music in human life through the introductory study of Western art music, world music, and jazz.  This course is open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major. Development of listening skills through introductory study of Western art music, world music, and jazz.

subrequirements.name: MUS 101A - Exploring Music through Piano for General Students

course.name: Exploring Music through Piano for General Students
course.full_name: MUS 101A - Exploring Music through Piano for General Students
course.description: This is an interactive course in music, open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.  This course explores the creative nature and process of making music at the piano. A goal of the course is to provide a basis for lifelong valuing of the musical experience and music making so that the student will continue with the piano as a source of self-expression and growth. The course introduces and develops an understanding of the basic concepts of music and the fundamentals of the keyboard. Improvisation and composition, sight-reading, playing by ear, harmonization, solo and ensemble keyboard repertoire, and applications of music technology will be creatively explored throughout the course.

subrequirements.name: MUS 100 - Basic Musicianship

course.name: Basic Musicianship
course.description: Introduction to the rudiments of musical notation, harmony, rhythm and melody.  This course is open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: MAS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music

course.name: Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.full_name: MAS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.description: Examination of the traditional folk music of Mexico and its influence.  This course covers the history and evolution of the mariachi as well as the vast potpourri of Mexican music traditions. A working knowledge of Spanish is helpful but not required.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: LAS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music

course.name: Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.full_name: LAS 337 - Survey of Mexican Folk Music
course.description: Examination of the traditional folk music of Mexico and its influence.  This course covers the history and evolution of the mariachi as well as the vast potpourri of Mexican music traditions. A working knowledge of Spanish is helpful but not required.  Open to all undergraduate University students, regardless of major.

subrequirements.name: LAS 322 - Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art

course.name: Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art
course.full_name: LAS 322 - Introduction to Prehispanic, Hispanic, and Chicano Art
course.description: Survey of the native, prehispanic arts of Meso; Central and South America; art since the conquest of Mexico, Central and South America; and Hispanic Arts of the Southwest and contemporary Chicano art.

subrequirements.name: JPN 245 - Japanese Anime and Visual Culture

course.name: Japanese Anime and Visual Culture
course.full_name: JPN 245 - Japanese Anime and Visual Culture
course.description: This course will explore contemporary Japanese society by investigating its colorful, dynamic, and rich output of visual culture. More specifically, we will look at manga, cinematic anime, and items of material culture, illustrating how these examples of popular art teach us about the various aspects of life in Japan.

subrequirements.name: ISTA 301 - Computing and the Arts

course.name: Computing and the Arts
course.description: This course examines the ways in which computing and information science support and facilitate the production and creation of art in current society. A particular focus of the course will be to discuss how artists have used advances in technology and computing capacity to explore new ways of making art, and to investigate the relationships between technical innovation and the artistic process.

subrequirements.name: HNRS 222 - Explorations in Creative Writing

course.name: Explorations in Creative Writing
course.description: Part critical studies and part writing workshop, this class engages students with various forms of creative writing (non-fiction, fiction, poetry, hybrid forms) with an emphasis on understanding writing as a craft-based discipline. Through close reading, analysis, writing, research, and participation in community events, students will generate and revise original critical and creative writing. The class will foster critical and creative synthesis through reading, discussion, invention, research, and revision.  The course is comprised of three phases; craft devices, research, and workshop.

prereq.description: Student must be active in the Honors College.

subrequirements.name: HNRS 216 - An Encounter with Poets and Their Poetry

course.name: An Encounter with Poets and Their Poetry
course.full_name: HNRS 216 - An Encounter with Poets and Their Poetry
course.description: This Honors course is taught in conjunction with the UA Visiting Poets and Writers Reading Series.  Class members read and discuss current work of the invited writers during class time, and attend several evening public readings sponsored by the Poetry Center.  Most writers attend the class for a discussion of their writing.  In addition to the critical study of contemporary writing, class members experiment with their own creative writing.

prereq.description: Student must be active in the Honors College.

subrequirements.name: HNRS 203H - Art as Awareness

course.name: Art as Awareness
course.description: What is art and what is art "for" are the central questions in this course.  Students will explore both the experience and the practice of art on a personal, social, cultural, political, and spiritual level.  This is an interdisciplinary course that will involve both a critical study and practice of art.  Students will engage in reading, writing, studio/gallery visits, and individual practice.

prereq.description: Student must be active in the Honors College.

course.name: Television and U.S. Culture
course.description: Survey of the three major eras of US television with attention to key programs, technology, critical reception, audience, and relation to other arts: broadcast era; cable era; transmedia era.

course.name: Looking at Movies: Film Styles and Genres

course.full_name: ENGL 210 - Introduction to the Writing of Fiction
course.description: Beginning techniques of fiction writing, taught through exercises, the writing of original fiction, and readings in contemporary fiction.

subrequirements.name: ENGL 209 - Introduction to the Writing of Poetry

course.name: Introduction to the Writing of Poetry
course.full_name: ENGL 209 - Introduction to the Writing of Poetry
course.description: Beginning techniques of poetry writing, taught through exercises, the writing of original poetry, and readings in contemporary poetry.

course.full_name: ENGL 201 - Introduction to the Writing of Creative Nonfiction

The course complements existing courses in poetry (ENGL209) and fiction (ENGL210).  All three courses are intended to improve undergraduate education by providing contact hours with Creative Writing faculty members early in the undergraduate's course of study.

course.name: History of Dance
course.description: History of dance in western civilization from ancient Egypt to the present.
